facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1004 of 1965 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 27, 1963 of the Calcutta High Court in Civil Rule No. 3723 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1004 of 1965. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 27, 1963 of the Calcutta High Court in Civil Rule No. 3723 of 1962.

facts.text: The appeal relates to a plot of land admeasuring about 41 decimals situate within the municipal limits of Chandernagore.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave relates to a plot of land admeasuring about - 41 decimals situate within the municipal limits of Chandernagore.

facts.text: Respondent No.1 is a society registered under the Societies Registration Act, XXXI of 1860.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No.1 is a society registered under the Societies Registration Act, XXXI of 1860.

facts.text: Objects of Respondent No.1 include to work, manage develop, improve and utilise properties and business for the promotion of education, art, science, religion and charity or other useful objects.

anchor.surface_text: Its objects as set out in clause 3 s  of its Memorandum of Association inter alia are to work, manage develop, improve and utilise properties and business for the promotion of education, art, science, religion and charity or other useful objects.

facts.text: On March 23, 1941, Kashinath Seal, owner of a large plot, granted permanent lease of the land in dispute to respondents 2 and 3.

anchor.surface_text: On March 23, 1941 one Kashinath Seal, the owner of a large plot of land, granted a permanent lease of the land in dispute out of the said plot in favour of respondents 2 and 3.

facts.text: By registered deed dated September 29, 1944, Kashinath Seal granted lease of entire plot including land in dispute to Motilal Roy for 99 years; for disputed land, Motilal Roy acquired only right of realising rent.

anchor.surface_text: By a registered deed of lease dated September 29, 1944 he granted lease of the entire plot of land including the land in dispute to one Motilal Roy for 99 years. So far as the land in dispute is companycerned, which as aforesaid was leased out to respondents 2 and 3, the said Motilal Roy acquired under this lease only the right of realising the rent.

facts.text: Motilal Roy was the founder of the 1st respondent Association and was a mere benamidar thereof.

anchor.surface_text: The said Motilal Roy was the founder of the 1st respondent Association and was a mere benamidar thereof.

facts.text: By deed of relinquishment dated March 14, 1953, Motilal Roy relinquished all his interest in the said plot in favour of the 1st respondent Association.

anchor.surface_text: By a deed of relinquishment dated March 14, 1953 he relinquished all his interest in the said plot in favour of the 1st respondent Association.

facts.text: By registered deed of sale with condition for reconveyance dated November 3, 1960, respondents 2 and 3 transferred the land in dispute to the appellant and handed over possession.

anchor.surface_text: By a registered deed of sale with a companydition for reconveyance dated November 3, 1960 respondents 2 and 3 transferred the land in dispute to the appellant and handed over its possession to him.

facts.text: 1st respondent Association made an application under section 24 of West Bengal Non-Agricultural Tenancy Act claiming right of transfer as immediate landlord, land contiguous to its lands, required for school extension.

anchor.surface_text: On companying to know of this sale the 1st respondent Association made an application claiming a right of transfer under section 24 of the West Bengal Non- Agricultural Tenancy Act, XX of 1949 on the ground, that it was the immediate landlord in relation to that land, that the land in question was companytiguous to its other lands and that it required it for the purpose of extension of the school companyducted by it.

facts.text: Trial Court dismissed the application holding land not contiguous to land in possession of 1st respondent but satisfied of bona fide requirement for expanding school.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court dismissed the application holding that the land in dispute was number companytiguous to the land in possession of the 1st respondent Association. It however held that it was satisfied that the 1st respondent Association required the said land bona fide for the purpose of expanding its school.

facts.text: Additional District Judge set aside Trial Court's finding on contiguity, held land adjacent, but held 1st respondent intermediary under WB Estates Acquisition Act 1954, interests vested in State after merger of Chandernagore, dismissed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: In an appeal against this order by the 1st respondent Association the Additional District Judge set aside the finding of the Trial Court holding that the land in dispute was adjacent to the other land in possession of the 1st respondent Association. But he held that the 1st respondent Association was an intermediary within the meaning of section 2 a  of the West Bengal Estates Acquisition Act, 1 of 1954 that therefore its interests vested in the State of West Bengal on the extension of the Act to Chandernagore after its merger in the State of West Bengal and companysequently respondent No.1 had numberright to claim transfer and dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: 1st respondent filed revision in High Court under section 116 CPC and Art. 227 Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The 1st respondent Association thereupon filed a revision application in the High Court under section 116 of the Code of Civil Procedure and Art. 227 of the Constitution.

facts.text: High Court repelled three contentions by appellant and allowed revision, setting aside dismissal orders.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court repelled all the three companytentions and allowed the revision setting aside the order of dismissal passed by the Trial Court and companyfirmed by the Additional District Judge.

facts.text: Land in dispute is contiguous to land in actual possession of 1st respondent Association.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the clear finding by the Additional District Judge it can numberlonger be disputed that the land in question is companytiguous to the land in actual possession of the 1st respondent Association.

facts.text: 1st respondent Association requires the land bona fide for expansion of its educational institution/school.

anchor.surface_text: There is also numberreason why the finding of the High Court that the land is bona fide required by the 1st respondent Association for expansion of its educational institution should be disturbed.

facts.text: Trial Court held land bona fide required by 1st respondent, Additional District Judge did not challenge it.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court held that it was bona fide required by the 1st -respondent and though the Additional District Judge did number expressly give any finding it appears as the High ,Court has stated that fact was number challenged before him.

facts.text: Respondents 2 and 3 are under-tenants of the 1st respondent Association.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore respondents 2 and 3 though ,under-tenants must be regarded tenants of the 1st respondent Association for the purposes of the Act.

facts.text: 1st respondent Association is the immediate landlord of respondents 2 and 3 regarding the land in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that by reason of the perpetual lease in favour of respondents 2 and 3 in respect of the land in dispute the first respondent Association had only the right of receiving rent from them but that makes numberdifference to the position that the first respondent war,, the immediate landlord of respondents 2 and 3 in regard to the land in question.

facts.text: 1st respondent Association is not an intermediary under section 2(1)(i) of West Bengal Estates Acquisition Act 1954 as it is a non-agricultural tenant.

anchor.surface_text: This companytention also cannot be accepted, for, an intermediary as defined in s. 2 1  i  of that Act means a proprietor, tenure-holder, under-tenure holder, or any other intermediary above a raiyit or a number-agricultural tenant and in relation to mines and minerals, a lessee or a sub- lessee It is thus obvious that the 1st respondent being itself a number-agricultural tenant in respect of the entire land including the land in dispute it does number fall within this definition.

facts.text: Chandernagore merged in the State of West Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: on the extension of the Act to Chandernagore after its merger in the State of West Bengal

facts.text: Appellant raised contention that 1st respondent was intermediary whose interests vested in State.

anchor.surface_text: Three companytentions were raised before the High Court on behalf of the present appellant  1  that the first respondent Association was. an intermediary within the meaning of S. 2 1  i  of the West Bengal Estates Acquisition Act and therefore all its rights vested under that Act in the State of West Bengal

facts.text: Appellant contended section 24 does not apply as land not contiguous and court not satisfied required for sec 4 purposes.

anchor.surface_text: 2  that section 24 of the Non- Agricultural Tenancy Act did number apply as  a  the land in dispute was number companytiguous,  b  that under proviso  b  to that section it must be established to the satisfaction of the Court that such land was required for any of the purposes specified in section 4 and that the companyrts below had number given any finding as to their satisfaction

facts.text: Appellant contended section 24 applies only to transfer by tenant, not under-tenant to third party.

anchor.surface_text: and  3  that section 24 did number apply to a case where an under- tenant transferred his rights to a third party as the section applied only to a transfer by a tenant.

But he held that the 1st respondent Association was an intermediary within the meaning of section 2 a of the West Bengal Estates Acquisition Act, 1 of 1954 that therefore its interests vested in the State of West Bengal

arguments.claim: Respondents 2 and 3 are under-tenants but must be regarded as tenants of the 1st respondent for purposes of the Act

anchor.surface_text: Therefore respondents 2 and 3 though under-tenants must be regarded tenants of the 1st respondent Association for the purposes of the Act.

arguments.claim: 1st respondent is immediate landlord of respondents 2 and 3

anchor.surface_text: It is true that by reason of the perpetual lease in favour of respondents 2 and 3 in respect of the land in dispute the first respondent Association had only the right of receiving rent from them but that makes no difference to the position that the first respondent was the immediate landlord of respondents 2 and 3 in regard to the land in question.

arguments.claim: 1st respondent not intermediary as it is itself a non-agricultural tenant

anchor.surface_text: This contention also cannot be accepted, for, an intermediary as defined in s. 2 1 i of that Act means a proprietor, tenure-holder, under-tenure holder, or any other intermediary above a raiyit or a non-agricultural tenant ... the 1st respondent being itself a non-agricultural tenant ... does number fall within this definition.

arguments.claim: Land required for purposes in s.4(b) business or (c) other purposes

anchor.surface_text: There is also no reason why the finding of the High Court that the land is bona fide required by the 1st respondent Association for expansion of its educational institution should be disturbed. ... the proviso to section 24 ... use for which it is needed must be for any of the purposes set out in section 4. ... falls under clause b and in any event under clause c.

arguments.claim: Section 24 not unreasonable as part of scheme for security of tenure to non-agricultural tenants

anchor.surface_text: An examination of the different provisions of the Act and its scheme shows that contiguity is not the sole consideration for which section 24 was enacted. ... The scheme of the Act clearly is to afford security of tenure to tenants and under tenants even to the extent of making their rights transferable and heritable.

holdings.text: The land in question is contiguous to the land in actual possession of the 1st respondent Association.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the clear finding by the Additional District Judge it can no longer be disputed that the land in question is contiguous to the land in actual possession of the 1st respondent Association.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts clear finding of Additional District Judge on contiguity, not disturbed on appeal.

holdings.text: The land is bona fide required by the 1st respondent Association for expansion of its educational institution and falls under section 4(b) or (c) of the West Bengal Non-Agricultural Tenancy Act.

anchor.surface_text: There is also no reason why the finding of the High Court that the land is bona fide required by the 1st respondent Association for expansion of its educational institution should be disturbed. The Trial Court held that it was bona fide required by the 1st -respondent and though the Additional District Judge did not expressly give any finding it appears as the High ,Court has stated that fact was not challenged before him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trial Court finding of bona fide requirement not challenged before Additional District Judge or High Court; educational expansion qualifies as business or other purpose under s.4(b)/(c).

holdings.text: Respondents 2 and 3 though under-tenants must be regarded as tenants of the 1st respondent Association for the purposes of the West Bengal Non-Agricultural Tenancy Act.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore respondents 2 and 3 though ,under-tenants must be regarded tenants of the 1st respondent Association for the purposes of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 3 defines two classes of non-agricultural tenants: tenants and under-tenants; both categories are 'tenants' for purposes of the Act including s.24.

holdings.text: The first respondent was the immediate landlord of respondents 2 and 3 in regard to the land in question.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that by reason of the perpetual lease in favour of respondents 2 and 3 in respect of the land in dispute the first respondent Association had only the right of receiving rent from them but that makes no difference to the position that the first respondent was the immediate landlord of respondents 2 and 3 in regard to the land in question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Perpetual lease granting only rent right does not alter immediate landlord status under s.2(3).

holdings.text: The 1st respondent Association is not an intermediary under section 2(1)(i) of the West Bengal Estates Acquisition Act as it is itself a non-agricultural tenant.

anchor.surface_text: This contention also cannot be accepted, for, an intermediary as defined in s. 2 1 i of that Act means a proprietor, tenure-holder, under-tenure holder, or any other intermediary above a raiyat or a non-agricultural tenant and in relation to mines and minerals, a lessee or a sub- lessee It is thus obvious that the 1st respondent being itself a non-agricultural tenant in respect of the entire land including the land in dispute it does not fall within this definition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory definition of intermediary excludes non-agricultural tenants; 1st respondent holds as non-agricultural tenant.

holdings.text: Section 24 of the West Bengal Non-Agricultural Tenancy Act does not constitute an unreasonable restriction on the right to hold property under Article 19(1)(f).

anchor.surface_text: An examination of the different provisions of the Act and its scheme shows that contiguity is not the sole consideration for which section 24 was enacted. ... The scheme of the Act clearly is to afford security of tenure to tenants and under tenants even to the extent of making their rights transferable and heritable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.24 part of broader scheme providing security of tenure, heritable/transferable rights to tenants; not solely vicinage-based pre-emption; distinguishes Bhau Ram on facts; reasonable public interest.

anchor.surface_text: In this companynection he relied upon Bhau Ram v. Baijnath Singh 1  where by a majority judgment this Court struck down section 10 of the Rewa State Pre-emption Act, 1946. That section provided for pre-emption on the ground of vicinage and it was held that such a restriction on the right of the vendor to sell his property to a purchaser of his choice at a price settled between them was unreasonable. It was observed that besides there being numberadvantage to the general public from such a law, the real reason  1  1962 Supp. 3 S. C. R. 724.

precedents.cited_proposition: pre-emption on the ground of vicinage constitutes an unreasonable restriction on the right to property
precedents.cited_holding: struck down section 10 of the Rewa State Pre-emption Act, 1946

anchor.surface_text: This is illustrated by Ram Sarup v. Munshi 1  where section 15 a  of the Punjab Pre-emption Act, 1913 , as amended by Act 10 of 1960 was held valid on the ground that the restriction on the right of free allienation imposed by that provision was intended to preserve the integrity of the village and the village companymunity and to implement the agnatic rule of succession and that both of them were reasonable and calculated to further the interests of the general public. 1 1963 3 S. C. R. 858.

precedents.cited_proposition: pre-emption right intended to preserve village integrity and implement agnatic succession is a reasonable restriction
precedents.cited_holding: section 15A of the Punjab Pre-emption Act, 1913 as amended held valid

anchor.surface_text: In view of the clear finding by the Additional District Judge it can no longer be disputed that the land in question is contiguous to the land in actual possession of the 1st respondent Association. There is also no reason why the finding of the High Court that the land is bona fide required by the 1st respondent Association for expansion of its educational institution should be disturbed.

edges.explanation: The concept application explains why s.24 is not an unreasonable restriction under Art.19, addressing the issue.
The description of the pre-emption right under s.24 as part of a scheme for tenant security, not solely based on vicinage, grounds the holding that it is not an unreasonable restriction.

The holding that Section 24 is not an unreasonable restriction is grounded in the rational nexus test, which deems restrictions reasonable if they serve public interest such as preserving village integrity.
The rational nexus test for reasonableness of restrictions under Article 19 directly addresses the issue of whether Section 24 constitutes an unreasonable restriction.

anchor.surface_text: This contention also cannot be accepted, for, an intermediary as defined in s. 2 1 i of that Act means a proprietor, tenure-holder, under-tenure holder, or any other intermediary above a raiyat or a non-agricultural tenant and in relation to mines and minerals, a lessee or a sub- lessee It is thus obvious that the 1st respondent being itself a non-agricultural tenant in respect of the entire land including the land in dispute it does not fall within this definition.

In view of the clear finding by the Additional District Judge it can no longer be disputed that the land in question is contiguous to the land in actual possession of the 1st respondent Association. There is also no reason why the finding of the High Court that the land is bona fide required by the 1st respondent Association for expansion of its educational institution should be disturbed.
